JUDGES: Javier Borrego Borrego;Karel Jungwiert;Margarita Tsatsa-Nikolovska;Mark Villiger;Peer Lorenzen;Renate Jaeger;Volodymyr Butkevych
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in the city of GPE , GPE . She was represented before the ORG by ORG , who resides in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
In DATE the applicant inherited a house with a plot of land . She subsequently had a land dispute with her neighbours , PERSON and PERSON , as to the limits of their respective plots .

On DATE the ORG of GPE found for the applicant in her dispute with PERSON concerning the border between their plots of land . On DATE the ORG quashed the decision of DATE and remitted the case for fresh consideration . The proceedings were subsequently terminated . On DATE the first - instance court issued a ruling on reversal of execution of the decision of DATE .
On DATE ORG of ORG of Kyiv ( hereafter “ the ORG ” ) decided that the limits of the plots should be in accordance with technical reports which had been drawn up in DATE .

On DATE the ORG of GPE found against the applicant in her dispute with PERSON as to the use of a shed situated on the border of the applicant ’s and G ’s plots of land . The court decided that , despite the fact that according to the technical reports of DATE the shed was situated on the applicant ’s plot of land , there were no documents which could prove the property rights for the shed in question . The court further found that according to the testimonies of witnesses , since DATE the shed had been used by the household in which PERSON lived .
On DATE ORG upheld in cassation the decision of the first - instance court .
On DATE , following the above judicial decisions , ORG invalidated its decision of DATE and approved the current limits of the plots in question . This decision was to the applicant ’s disadvantage .

In DATE the applicant instituted proceedings in the Shevchenkivsky ORG of GPE against PERSON , PERSON and ORG , challenging the decision of DATE and requesting that all obstacles to her free use of her land be removed .

In DATE and DATE the court ordered forensic expert reports to be drawn up in the case . The first concluded that the actual limits of the land plots did not correspond to the technical documentation , and the second concluded that the actual limits corresponded to the decision of ORG of DATE .

At the court hearing of DATE the applicant sought to introduce an additional claim seeking the invalidation of land ownership certificates issued to PERSON and NORP in DATE . The defendants objected to this new claim as unrelated and noted that the applicant could submit it separately . The court subsequently rejected this additional claim within the impugned proceedings .

On DATE the Shevchenkivsky ORG of GPE found against the applicant , having established that she had challenged the decision of DATE outside the statutory time - limit and that the actual border between the plots of land , as confirmed by the forensic report , corresponded to the decision of DATE . Given the validity of the decision of DATE the court rejected the remainder of the applicant ’s arguments as unfounded .
On DATE the ORG upheld the judgment of DATE . On DATE the applicant posted a cassation appeal , which was received by the court on DATE .

On DATE the Shevchenkivsky ORG rejected the applicant ’s request for a cassation appeal as having been submitted too late . The court stated that , under the new wording of LAW ( hereafter “ the ORG ” ) , which had entered into force on DATE , the time - limit for lodging an appeal in cassation was DATE , and that the applicant had exceeded that time - limit by only submitting her appeal on DATE .

On DATE ORG upheld the ruling of DATE , stating that the applicant had lodged her appeal on DATE , which had been outside the new DATE time - limit established by law , and had not requested an extension of the time - limit for lodging such an appeal .
On DATE the applicant ’s representative lodged an appeal in cassation against the rulings of DATE and DATE .

On DATE ORG returned the appeal to the first - instance court to decide on compliance of the appeal with procedural formalities , namely on the fact that the applicant ’s representative had submitted the cassation appeal on her own behalf and not on behalf of the applicant .

By a ruling of DATE the ORG requested that the applicant ’s representative bring the cassation appeal in compliance with procedural formalities and fixed the deadline for doing so at DATE . The representative resubmitted the appeal with the same shortcomings .
On DATE the first - instance court returned the cassation appeal without consideration for failure to comply with procedural formalities .
On DATE ORG upheld the ruling of DATE .
The applicant appealed in cassation .
On DATE the ORG requested that the applicant ’s representative bring the cassation appeal in compliance with procedural formalities and fixed the deadline for doing so at DATE .
By ruling of CARDINAL DATE the same court extended the deadline for the applicant ’s representative to submit her corrected cassation appeal to DATE .
On DATE a panel of CARDINAL judges of ORG rejected the applicant ’s request for leave to appeal in cassation against the rulings of DATE and DATE .

At the time of the second - instance decision on appeal , the first paragraph of LAW ORG provided that a cassation appeal should be lodged within DATE of the decision on appeal or within DATE of the decision of the first - instance court , if the latter decision was not appealed against under the normal appeal procedure .

On DATE ORG passed a law amending the ORG ( hereafter “ LAW ” ) , including LAW in question . It came into force on DATE . The new wording of Article CARDINAL created a DATE time - limit for lodging a cassation application against the decision of an appellate court .
